review.title: Strategic Argumentation is NP-Complete
review.abstract: In this paper we study the complexity of strategic argumentation for dialogue games. A dialogue game is a 2-player game where the parties play arguments. We show how to model dialogue games in a skeptical, non-monotonic formalism, and we show that the problem of deciding what move (set of rules) to play at each turn is an NP-complete problem.

sections.heading: 7 Summary
sections.text: In the following (Okuno and Takahashi 2009; Satoh and Takahashi 2011), we argue that argumentation games work with incomplete information: Each player does not know the other player's knowledge, so he cannot predict which arguments will be attacked and which counter-arguments will be used to attack the arguments; therefore, arguments can disclose such private information, allowing the other player to attack. Although it is outside the scope of this essay how strategic dialogues can be analyzed in game theory terms, our research efforts precede this analysis, since they examine the calculation costs for the logical characterization of the problem, that any argumentation game with incomplete information potentially increases. We have shown that the problem of deciding which rules to play ("Strategic Argumentation Problem") is NP-complete even when the problem of restoring a given theory (incomplete) potentially raises a problem with incomplete information.
